shot_context.definition: Front-foot, off-side stroke with emphasis on timing, balance, and directional control; not a power-hitting shot.

measurement_clarification.interpretation_note: Small magnitudes indicate a compact, near-vertical backlift and are not treated as an error.

what_went_right: The stroke shows a clear shift of body load toward the front side during the downswing.
The bat backlift is compact and close to vertical through the load phase.
Upper-body separation increases into the downswing window.
what_went_wrong: Weight transfer rate changes sharply around the load-to-downswing transition.
The load phase shows large variability in hipâ€“shoulder separation.
Lead knee flexion reduces substantially from load into downswing.

what_went_right.coach_point: Front-side loading occurs through the downswing window.
what_went_right.data_backing: Weight-transfer metrics show WT decreasing from 0.5076381985682026 (FrontBar 0.4923618014317974) at frame 230 to 0.1975417071251884 (FrontBar 0.8024582928748116) at frame 259 within P3 (frames 230-259).

citation.authors: Kevin L. Peploe, David B. Pyne, Ross Sanders
citation.title: The effect of lower-limb biomechanics on batting performance in cricket

what_went_right.coach_point: Backlift remains compact relative to vertical at the end of the load phase.
what_went_right.data_backing: Bat backlift angle is 3.8981842427372135 degrees at frame 229, which lies in P2 (frames 151-229); angle is defined relative to vertical (0° vertical).

citation.authors: Michael C. Stuelcken, David B. Pyne, Ross Sanders
citation.title: Biomechanical comparison of cricket batting strokes: backlift, downswing, and follow-through mechanics

what_went_right.coach_point: Hip–shoulder separation increases into the downswing phase.

citation.title: Biomechanical analysis of selected cricket batting strokes

what_went_wrong.coach_point: Weight-transfer rate changes sharply around the start of downswing.
what_went_wrong.data_backing: WTdot is -1.2039462048140783 at frame 229 (end of P2) and -1.1863970959194916 at frame 230 (start of P3); earlier in P2, WTdot is -0.3598032069970832 at frame 151.

citation.title: Enhancing cricket batting skill: implications of biomechanics and motor learning

what_went_wrong.coach_point: Hip–shoulder separation varies widely during the load phase.
what_went_wrong.data_backing: During P2 (frames 151-229), hip–shoulder separation has std 7.238688190987991 degrees with a range from 0.528669542123892 to 28.297600307549697 degrees.

citation.authors: Michael C. Stuelcken, David B. Pyne, Ross Sanders
citation.title: Biomechanical comparison of cricket batting strokes: backlift, downswing, and follow-through mechanics

what_went_wrong.coach_point: Lead knee flexion reduces substantially from load into downswing.

citation.title: Kinematic analysis of front-foot drives in cricket batting

sequencing_and_kinetic_chain.coach_point: Observed peak order is trunk → lead_arm → pelvis based on explicit peak frames in P3.
sequencing_and_kinetic_chain.data_backing: In P3, trunk_peak_frame=237, lead_arm_peak_frame=253, pelvis_peak_frame=259; peaks occur in the order 237 → 253 → 259.

citation.authors: Michael C. Stuelcken, David B. Pyne, Ross Sanders
citation.title: Biomechanical comparison of cricket batting strokes: backlift, downswing, and follow-through mechanics

bat_swing_speed_P3_mean.notes: Mean bat swing speed computed over downswing phase (P3) as provided.

visuals.reason: Frame-wise images were provided separately and were not analyzed per instruction.

phase_coverage.notes: P1 not present in derived phase_definitions; analysis uses only provided phases.

side_metrics_notes: weight_transfer_per_frame covers frames 0-533; pose frames cover 0-375. Analysis uses the overlapping range from the start as required.
